metadata.title: World War I
metadata.description: From a gunshot in Sarajevo to a four-year war that changed the world. Explore how a local conflict escalated into a global catastrophe.

hero.quote: World War I was a global military conflict that occurred between 1914 and 1918.
hero.quoteBreak1: Marked by the assassination in Sarajevo in June 1914,
hero.quoteBreak2: it ended with the German Empire signing the armistice in November 1918.

howItStarted.title: How the War Began
howItStarted.paragraph1: Since the 19th century, Slavic peoples had been under the oppression of the German, Austro-Hungarian, and Ottoman empires. As nationalism spread across Europe, South Slavs' desire for common identity grew stronger, and national consciousness gradually awakened.
howItStarted.paragraph2: Serbia, predominantly South Slavic and one of the few independent Slavic nations, actively participated in the South Slav movement. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, organizations like Young Bosnia rapidly radicalized under anti-Austrian sentiment and Serbian support, deepening ethnic tensions.
howItStarted.paragraph3: Ultimately, extreme nationalism turned to violence, triggering a political crisis with the assassination in Sarajevo.

event1.text: Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary was assassinated in Sarajevo by members of Young Bosnia

event2.text: Germany pledged unconditional support to Austria-Hungary, whatever actions it took
event2.note: Unified in 1871, the German Empire faced geopolitical pressure with 'Russia to the east, France to the west.' To avoid a two-front war, Germany adopted a policy of 'allying with Austria-Hungary, resisting France and Russia.' After Ferdinand's assassination, Germany issued a 'blank check' to Austria-Hungary to preserve the alliance system and contain Slavic nationalism.

event3.text: Austria-Hungary issued an ultimatum to Serbia containing ten demands
event3.note: Some demands were particularly harsh, such as requiring Serbia to allow Austro-Hungarian officials to enter its territory to investigate the assassination.

event4.text: Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia. The local conflict officially began

escalation.title: How the War Spiraled Out of Control
escalation.subtitle: From a local war to a global conflict

point1.title: July 29-30: Russia's Full Mobilization (Chain Reaction Begins)
point1.description: Facing Austria-Hungary's declaration of war on Serbia, Russia initiated war mobilization first. As the most powerful Slavic nation, Russia styled itself as the protector of Slavic peoples. Allowing Austria-Hungary's attack on Serbia would undermine Russia's influence in the Balkans.

point2.title: August 1: Germany Declares War on Russia
point2.description: In 1914's war culture, whoever struck first held the strategic advantage. To preempt, Germany immediately declared war on Russia after its mobilization. Germany decided to execute the 'Schlieffen Plan' - attack France first, then Russia.

point3.title: August 3: Invasion of Belgium
point3.description: Germany declared war on France and invaded Belgium when it refused passage. To avoid France's fortified eastern defenses, Germany planned to invade through Belgium from northeastern France.

point4.title: August 4: Britain Declares War on Germany
point4.description: In the 1839 Treaty of London, European powers agreed Belgium would be permanently neutral. Germany's invasion not only violated the treaty but directly threatened the British Isles across the Channel. To contain German dominance of Europe, Britain immediately declared war on Germany.

scale.title: Scale of the War
scale.subtitle: A global catastrophe
scale.note: The world population at the time was approximately 1.7 billion, with 67 million mobilized,
scale.noteBreak: equivalent to 1 in every 25 people participating in this war

phases.title: The War's Progression
phases.subtitle: Evolution of four years of war

stage1.title: Initial Outbreak
stage1.subtitle: Initial Outbreak
stage1.description: In early stages, nations harbored fantasies of quick victory. The Western Front reached stalemate after the Battle of the Marne, with both sides digging trenches.

stage2.title: Stalemate
stage2.subtitle: Stalemate
stage2.description: The Western Front entered full trench warfare. Battles of Verdun and Somme brought massive casualties with little progress. This was brutal war of attrition.

stage3.title: Turning Point
stage3.subtitle: Turning Point
stage3.description: Russia withdrew from the Allies, America entered the war. Two decisive events fundamentally changed the war's dynamics.

stage4.title: Collapse
stage4.subtitle: Collapse
stage4.description: Central Powers retreated under Allied counteroffensive. On November 11, armistice was signed, officially ending World War I.

russia.subtitle: Russia Withdraws from the Allies
russia.content: World War I devastated Russia's domestic situation. Prolonged war brought the economy to the brink of collapse. In February 1917, massive worker and peasant revolutionary movements erupted in St. Petersburg, forcing the Tsar's abdication. In March 1918, the Soviet government formally reached an agreement with Germany and withdrew from World War I.

america.subtitle: America Enters the War
america.content: America pursued neutrality in early WWI. As war progressed, Germany's unrestricted submarine warfare caused American casualties and property losses. The Zimmermann Telegram revealed Germany's plot to help Mexico reclaim lost territories. On April 6, 1917, America declared war on Germany.

political.title: Political Landscape
political.content: WWI led to the complete dissolution of the German, Austro-Hungarian, Ottoman, and Russian empires. The victors established the post-war international order at the Paris Peace Conference (1919), forming the Versailles System. At its core was the Treaty of Versailles punishing Germany, and the League of Nations to maintain peace.

economic.title: Economic
economic.content: Major European belligerents exhausted vast human, material, and financial resources, burdened with enormous war debts. Many industrial and agricultural regions were destroyed, production severely declined. Meanwhile, America's economy achieved unprecedented prosperity, and Japan became Asia's sole imperialist power.

warTrauma.subtitle: War Trauma
warTrauma.content: The war caused tens of millions of deaths and injuries. This scale of sacrifice was unprecedented, shattering people's illusions about the 'glory' and 'heroism' of war.

womenStatus.subtitle: Elevated Women's Status
womenStatus.content: The war caused massive male casualties, creating urgent labor needs in factories and farms, leading women to enter fields traditionally dominated by men on a large scale. This changed societal perceptions of women's roles and advanced women's political rights, including suffrage, in the post-war period.

epilogue.footnote: — Yet history tells us, this was only the beginning
